bibl.title: Timeline of Aristides Agramonte's service with the Army Medical Corps, [19--]

div1.p: This document details Agramonte's career; from April 18, 1898 to June 15, 1903.

div1.head: Timeline of Aristides Agramonte's service with the Army Medical Corps, [19--]

list.item: A = Agramonte
1898 April 18 A. to Sternberg offering services to Army Medical Corps.

April 19 Sternberg to A asking whether A had had any experience with
yellow fever or had had the disease. (I cannot locate A's
answer.)

May 3 Acting Assistant Surgeon Agramonte assigned to temporary duty
under Reed in Path Lab., S.G.O., Wash. D.C.

July 15 A. ordered to proceed from Washington to New York and via
U.S.S. Resolute to report to General Shafter for duty
in yellow fever hospital at Santiago de Cuba.

July 25 Arrived in Santiago de Cuba; went to Siboney, then back to
Santiago (Letter of A to Sternberg, July 29, 1898).
Nov. ___ Returned to Washington (See A's letter to Kelly, March 22, 1905).

November 24 A. ordered by Sternberg to proceed from Wash. to Havana to study
yellow fever under direction of the Chief Surgeon at Havana.

1899 April 17 A. submitted to Sternberg (Wash)oreport0fromsyellow fever
Hospital No. 3 at Havana.
June 17 A. submitted another report to Sternberg.

July 9 Missing letter of A. to Sternberg (This letter mentioned in
another letter that I cannot find).
July 21 A. in yellow fever hospital Santiago; letter from Sternberg to A.
August 9 A. left Santiago, returned to Havana
August 15 A. at Las Animas Hospital, Havana; sent report to Sternberg.

November 14 A. was apparently at U. S. Military Hosp. No. 1, Havana;
letter from Reed in Wash. addressed thus to A.

December 13 Sternberg to A. re A.'s report to be sent to Medical News
(published February 1900).

December 24 Letter from A. at U. S. Military Hosp. No. 1 to Sternberg (Wash)
stating he wished to solicit the new chair of Bacteriology
at the U. of Havana.

December 29 Sternberg to A. stating A's contract will be annulled as of
January 15, 1900.

1900 January 8 A.'s contract not to be annulled yet: Sternberg cable to DeWitt,
Chief Surgeon, Havana.

January 26 A. still working at U. S. Military Hospital No. 1, Havana
(Sternberg to A.).

March 2 Sternberg to DeWitt suggesting annulment of A's contract unless
his services needed elsewhere as pathologist and bacteriologist.

March 29 A. transferred from Military Hospital #1, to report to Chief
Surgeon, Dept. of Havana.

April 25 A. assigned for duty in charge of the Department Laboratory,
Dept. of Havana.
May 11 Sternberg to A., making research suggestions.

May 23 A. transferred from Dept. of Havana and Pinar del Rio to
report to the Chief Surgeon of the Division for duty in
charge of the Division Laboratory (Division of Cuba).
May 24 A. appointed to Yellow Fever Board (Par. 24, S.O., 122, A.G.O., Wash.).
June 27 A. ordered to visit Santa Clara and return to Havana.
Page 2

July 17 A. ordered to visit Pinar del Rio to study epidemic of
“pernicious fever.”
August ___ Passed exams for M.D. degree, U. of Havana (see 1905 letter to Kelly).

September___ Obtained by competitive exam the chair of Bacterioloty and
Experimental Pathology in the U. of Havana (Still held
this in 1905; see letter to Kelly).
September 1 A. renewed contract at $150.00 a month.

September 20 A. wrote letter to General Wood requesting permission to go
to New York to purchase laboratory apparatus for U. of
Havana.
September 20. Scott to A.; telling A. to apply for leave of absence for 15 days.

September 21 Fifteen day “leave” granted (S.O. 164, Hdqts. Division of Cuba)
(This “leave” was not counted against A.).

September 22 Wood to A.: authority to go to New York to buy $3,000 worth
of laboratory equipment for U. of Havana.

September 24 A. left Havana presumably on the transport Sedgewick
(Carroll, on Sept. 23, 1900, wrote his wife: “Agramonte
left for New York yesterday with his wife.”)

October 5 A. in New York; left orders with Bausch and Lomb Optical Co.,
and with Leitz Co.

October 12 A. arrived back in Havana, returning from New York apparently
on the transport Sedgewick.

October 12 - 31 On duty in charge of Division Laboratory and also as member of
Yellow Fever Board.
(See A's own Personal Reports dated Sept. 1, October 1,
November 1, 1900 and sent to the S.G.).

October 16 A's 15 day leave of absence was extended 3 days (S.O., 182,
Hdqts., Div. of Cuba) as he had been away 18 instead of 15 days.
October 23 A. authorized to go to and fro between Quemados and Havana.

1901 May 16 Major Havard to S.G., Wash., inquiring whether A. has been
relieved from the (yellow fever) Board.

May 21 Sternberg to A.G., Wash., recommending that A. be relieved from
duty on the Yellow Fever Board. and to report to the Commanding
General, Dept. of Cuba, for assignment to duty.

May 21 Cable of Corbin (Adj. General) to Wood (Havana) relieving A.
from duty with Yellow Fever Board (S.O. 118, A.G.O., Wash, D.C.)

May 28 A. assigned to duty in charge of the Dept. Laboratory at Municipal
Municipal Hospital No. 1 and of the microscopical and bacterio-
logical work at Las Animas Hospital (S.O. 117, Hdqts. Dept.
Cuba, Havana, May 28, 1901).

June 20 A. ordered to visit Post Hospital, Columbia Barracks 4 days a
week (in addition to present duties) (S.O. 134, Hdqts. Dept.
of Cuba).
July 16 A. relieved from Las Animas Hospital duties.
July 26 Leave of absence for one month granted (July 28 - Aug. 21).

1902 March 26 Sternberg to A. notifying him his contract will be annulled on
April 30, 1902.

May 8 Gorgas to Sternberg: A's contract to be ended May 15, 1902 (But
was it annulled then? Apparently not.).
August 13 A. to Sternberg sending his contract for annulment on August 15.

May 16-Aug. 15 On leave of absence (See letter to A. from Paymaster General,
January 13, 1903).
Page 3

1903 February 10 S.G. authorized to employ A. as contract-surgeon for temporary
service at Cabana Barracks, Cuba at $100.00 a month.
June 15 Contract annulled.
